message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient has anemia caused by extravascular hemolysis and the presentation of spherocytes suggest a defect in spectrin, a protein that helps give shape and stability to RBCs. Iron absorption affects the amount of iron in the body and is not related to RBC shape. Glucose-6-phosphatase dehydrogenase and glycosylphosphatidylinositol are not directly involved in RBC structure/function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of spherical RBCs indicates a defect in the membrane, and among the options, only spectrin is a major component of the erythrocyte membrane. Iron absorption defects lead to iron deficiency anemia, G6PD deficiency causes hemolytic anemia due to oxidative stress, and GPI anchor deficiency causes paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s anemia is caused by extravascular hemolysis, which is often due to a genetic defect in spectrin, an important component of the RBC cytoskeleton. Iron absorption defects would lead to a different type of anemia, while glucose-6-phosphatase dehydrogenase and glycosylphosphatidylinositol defects are associated with hemolytic anemias but not specifically extravascular hemolysis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. An autosomal dominant disorder causing anemia by extravascular hemolysis suggests hereditary spherocytosis, which is caused by defects in red blood cell membrane proteins. Spectrin is a structural protein found in the red blood cell membrane and mutations in spectrin genes are the most common cause of hereditary spherocytosis. Iron absorption defects can cause iron-deficiency anemia but not hereditary spherocytosis. Glucose-6-phosphatase dehydrogenase and Glycosylphosphatidylinositol are not involved in RBC membrane structure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The autosomal dominant disorder that causes anemia by extravascular hemolysis with spherical RBCs suggests hereditary spherocytosis. Among the options, only Spectrin is a component of the cytoskeleton of RBCs and defects in it can cause hereditary spherocytosis. Iron absorption defects do not cause spherocytosis. Glucose-6-phosphatase dehydrogenase and Glycosylphosphatidylinositol  defects cause different types of anemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The autosomal dominant disorder causing anemia by extravascular hemolysis with spherical RBCs indicates hereditary spherocytosis, which is caused by defects in spectrin or other proteins involved in the RBC membrane. Iron absorption and glucose-6-phosphatase dehydrogenase are not related to RBC shape or lifespan. Glycosylphosphatidylinositol is involved in anchoring proteins to the cell membrane but is not implicated in hereditary spherocytosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. An autosomal dominant disorder that causes anemia by extravascular hemolysis with spherical-shaped RBCs suggests hereditary spherocytosis. This disorder is primarily caused by defective spectrin, which leads to decreased flexibility of RBCs and their premature destruction. Iron absorption is not related to this disorder, and glucose-6-phosphatase dehydrogenase and glycosylphosphatidylinositol deficiencies cause different forms of anemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Spherical RBCs are a characteristic of hereditary spherocytosis, which is caused by a defect in spectrin, an important protein in the RBC cytoskeleton. Iron absorption is important in the pathogenesis of iron-deficiency anemia but not in hereditary spherocytosis. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency causes oxidative damage to RBCs, but it does not cause spherical RBCs. Glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors are important for attaching proteins to RBC membranes but do not play a role in the pathogenesis of hereditary spherocytosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The autosomal dominant disorder causing anemia by extravascular hemolysis suggests hereditary spherocytosis, which is caused by defects in the RBC membrane proteins. Among the options, only spectrin is a RBC membrane protein. Iron absorption is unrelated to RBC shape, and Glucose-6-phosphatase dehydrogenase and Glycosylphosphatidylinositol are not involved in RBC membrane structure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The disorder causing anemia by extravascular hemolysis with spherical RBCs is hereditary spherocytosis, which is caused by a defect in the spectrin protein. Iron absorption is related to iron-deficiency anemia, glucose-6-phosphatase dehydrogenase is related to hemolytic anemia caused by oxidative stress, and glycosylphosphatidylinositol is related to paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.
